title: Planning Operation Overlord
subtitle: The strategic preparation for the largest amphibious invasion in history
overview: Explore the massive logistical and strategic planning that went into preparing D-Day, from the selection of Normandy to the elaborate deception operations.
keyIdeas: Why Normandy was chosen over Pas-de-Calais
Operation Fortitude and the deception campaign

cards.title: The Selection of Normandy
cards.content: Normandy was chosen over the Pas-de-Calais despite the latter being closer to England. The decision was based on several factors: weaker German defenses, better beach conditions, and the element of surprise. The Allies knew that Germany expected an attack at Calais, making it heavily fortified.
cards.frenchPerspective: For Normans, the choice of their region for the invasion would bring both liberation and tremendous destruction. Many civilians were unaware their homeland would become the decisive battlefield.

cards.title: Operation Fortitude
cards.content: Operation Fortitude was an elaborate deception plan to convince Germany that the main invasion would target the Pas-de-Calais. It included fake army units, inflatable tanks and aircraft, false radio traffic, and double agents. General Patton commanded the fictional First U.S. Army Group (FUSAG).

title: The Five Beaches
subtitle: Utah, Omaha, Gold, Juno, and Sword - the assault sectors
overview: Learn about each of the five invasion beaches, the forces assigned to them, and the unique challenges they faced on June 6, 1944.
keyIdeas: Beach obstacles and Atlantic Wall defenses

cards.title: Utah Beach
cards.content: Utah Beach was the westernmost landing zone, assigned to the U.S. 4th Infantry Division. Due to strong currents, troops landed about 2,000 yards south of the intended target - which proved fortunate as defenses were lighter there. Brigadier General Theodore Roosevelt Jr. famously declared 'We'll start the war from right here!'

cards.title: Omaha Beach
cards.content: Omaha Beach witnessed the bloodiest fighting of D-Day. The U.S. 1st and 29th Infantry Divisions faced steep cliffs, strong defenses, and the elite German 352nd Infantry Division. Nearly 2,400 Americans became casualties. The beach was nicknamed 'Bloody Omaha.'
cards.frenchPerspective: The villages of Vierville, Saint-Laurent, and Colleville behind Omaha Beach were devastated. Many French civilians had been evacuated, but some remained and witnessed the carnage.

cards.title: Gold Beach
cards.content: Gold Beach was the central British landing zone, assigned to the 50th (Northumbrian) Infantry Division. Despite rough seas that delayed the DD tanks, British forces secured the beach and advanced inland, eventually linking with Canadian forces from Juno.

cards.title: Juno Beach
cards.content: Juno Beach was Canada's assault sector, where the 3rd Canadian Infantry Division faced heavy resistance. Delayed by rough seas, the Canadians suffered high casualties in the first hour but ultimately advanced the farthest inland of any beach on D-Day.

cards.title: Sword Beach
cards.content: Sword Beach was the easternmost landing zone, assigned to the British 3rd Infantry Division. Their objective included linking up with the airborne forces at Pegasus Bridge and capturing Caen - though the city would not fall for over a month.

title: Airborne Operations
subtitle: The paratroopers and glider forces who secured the flanks
overview: Discover the crucial role of American and British airborne forces who dropped behind enemy lines in the early hours of D-Day.
keyIdeas: The importance of securing the flanks

cards.title: The Night Drops
cards.content: Beginning shortly after midnight on June 6, over 24,000 American and British paratroopers and glider troops descended into Normandy. Poor weather and German anti-aircraft fire scattered many units far from their drop zones, but this confusion also bewildered German defenders.

cards.title: Pegasus Bridge
cards.content: In one of the most daring operations of D-Day, British glider troops led by Major John Howard captured the bridges over the Caen Canal and Orne River intact. Landing within 50 yards of their objective, they secured the vital crossings in just 10 minutes.

cards.title: Sainte-Mere-Eglise
cards.content: Sainte-Mere-Eglise became the first French town liberated on D-Day. Paratroopers of the 82nd Airborne landed in and around the town while a fire was burning, illuminating them for German defenders. Private John Steele's parachute famously caught on the church steeple.
cards.frenchPerspective: The townspeople of Sainte-Mere-Eglise witnessed the battle firsthand. Despite the danger, some French civilians helped wounded paratroopers and hid them from German patrols.
